fundamental-rights.title: My Fundamental Rights
fundamental-rights.introduction: Fundamental Rights are the basic human rights enshrined in the Constitution of India which are guaranteed to all citizens. These rights are essential for the all-round development of individuals and the country.

sections.heading: Right to Equality (Articles 14-18)
sections.content: Ensures equality before law, prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth, and abolishes untouchability and titles.

sections.heading: Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22)
sections.content: Includes freedom of speech and expression, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession. Also includes protection in respect of conviction for offences.

sections.heading: Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24)
sections.content: Prohibits human trafficking, forced labor, and employment of children in factories and hazardous work.

sections.heading: Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28)
sections.content: Guarantees freedom of conscience and free profession, practice and propagation of religion.

sections.heading: Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30)
sections.content: Protects the interests of minorities and their right to establish and administer educational institutions.

sections.heading: Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)
sections.content: Empowers citizens to move to the Supreme Court for enforcement of their Fundamental Rights.

keyPoints: Fundamental Rights can be suspended during a national emergency
Article 21 (Right to Life) is the most important fundamental right
The Supreme Court is the guardian of Fundamental Rights

preamble.title: What is the Preamble?
preamble.introduction: The Preamble is the introductory statement of the Constitution that sets out the guiding purpose and principles of the document. It declares India to be a sovereign, socialist, secular, democratic republic.

sections.heading: Text of the Preamble
sections.content: WE, THE PEOPLE OF INDIA, having solemnly resolved to constitute India into a SOVEREIGN SOCIALIST SECULAR DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC and to secure to all its citizens: JUSTICE, social, economic and political; LIBERTY of thought, expression, belief, faith and worship; EQUALITY of status and of opportunity; and to promote among them all FRATERNITY assuring the dignity of the individual and the unity and integrity of the Nation; IN OUR CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY this twenty-sixth day of November, 1949, do HEREBY ADOPT, ENACT AND GIVE TO OURSELVES THIS CONSTITUTION.

sections.heading: Key Words Explained
sections.content: SOVEREIGN: India is independent and not under any external power. SOCIALIST: Wealth is generated socially and shared equitably. SECULAR: No state religion; all religions are treated equally. DEMOCRATIC: Government by the people, of the people, for the people. REPUBLIC: Head of state is elected, not hereditary.

keyPoints: The words 'Socialist' and 'Secular' were added by the 42nd Amendment in 1976
The Preamble can be amended but its basic structure cannot be changed
It embodies the basic philosophy and fundamental values of the Constitution

student-duties.title: My Duties as a Student Citizen
student-duties.introduction: As a young citizen of India, you have certain fundamental duties towards your nation. These duties help in building a strong and united India.

sections.heading: Respect the Constitution
sections.content: Abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions, the National Flag and the National Anthem.

sections.heading: Cherish Our Heritage
sections.content: Cherish and follow the noble ideals which inspired our national struggle for freedom and protect our composite culture.

sections.heading: Environmental Protection
sections.content: Protect and improve the natural environment including forests, lakes, rivers, wildlife and have compassion for living creatures.

sections.heading: Excel in Education
sections.content: Develop scientific temper, humanism and the spirit of inquiry and reform. Strive towards excellence in all spheres of individual and collective activity.

keyPoints: Fundamental Duties were added by the 42nd Amendment in 1976
There are 11 Fundamental Duties in total
As a student, focus on education, environmental protection, and respecting diversity

cyber-laws.title: Cyber Laws & Safety
cyber-laws.introduction: In the digital age, it's important to understand your rights and responsibilities online. India has comprehensive cyber laws to protect citizens in the digital space.

sections.heading: Information Technology Act, 2000
sections.content: The IT Act is India's primary law dealing with cybercrime and electronic commerce. It provides legal recognition to electronic transactions and penalizes cyber offenses.

sections.heading: Common Cyber Crimes
sections.content: Cyberbullying, identity theft, hacking, phishing, online fraud, data theft, and spreading misinformation are all punishable offenses under Indian law.

sections.heading: Online Safety Tips
sections.content: Use strong passwords, enable two-factor authentication, be careful about sharing personal information, verify sources before clicking links, and report suspicious activities.

sections.heading: Your Digital Rights
sections.content: You have the right to privacy online, the right to be forgotten, and the right to protect your personal data.

keyPoints: Cyberbullying is a punishable offense - report it immediately
Never share your passwords or personal information online
Think before you post - digital footprints are permanent

elections.title: Understanding Elections
elections.introduction: Elections are the foundation of democracy. Understanding how elections work helps you become an informed and responsible citizen.

sections.heading: Electoral System in India
sections.content: India follows a first-past-the-post system for Lok Sabha and Vidhan Sabha elections. The candidate with the most votes wins, even without an absolute majority.

sections.heading: Election Commission of India
sections.content: An autonomous constitutional authority responsible for administering election processes in India. It ensures free and fair elections.

sections.heading: Voting Process
sections.content: Citizens aged 18 and above can vote. Voting is done through Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) and NOTA (None of the Above) option is available.

sections.heading: Student Participation
sections.content: While you may not be able to vote yet, you can participate by spreading awareness, volunteering during elections, and understanding political issues.

keyPoints: India is the world's largest democracy
Voting age was reduced from 21 to 18 by the 61st Amendment in 1989
Your vote is your voice - make it count when you turn 18
